abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the First Agricultural
            Services Project for Guinea was unsatisfactory. The project
            did not achieve its objectives, institutional development
            was negligible, sustainability is unlikely, and the
            performance of both the Bank and Borrower was
            unsatisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, project processing should follow the normal
            stages of the project cycle. Second, one issue that could
            and should have been discussed is whether IDA has a
            comparative advantage in the provision of technical
            assistance on a credit basis vis-�vis the grant financing
            that can be provided by bilateral donors and UNDP. Third, in
            a situation where institutions are weak, project design
            should be kept simple and the number of components limited.
            Fourth, institutional building components should have clear
            objectives in terms of transferring skills, training
            programs, performance yardsticks for consultants, and
            transfer of responsibilities. Finally, the expected
            budgetary contributions from the Government should be put at
            a realistic level that is consistent with its resource
            availability as ascertained by IDA at the macroeconomic and
            not the sectoral level.
